entry.title: Back to Octopress Master
entry.content:
After playing with the link log feature in the Octopress 2.1, and now 3.0, branches, I’ve decided to come back to the master branch. Octopress 3.0 looks like it’s going to be very nice, but things are too unstable for me at the moment. I shouldn’t be spending so much time hacking on the site itself when there is actual work to do.

For the linklog posts I’ve already made, I just edited the entry with a link to the external URL in the body of the post. Apologies if this causes repeat entries to appear in your RSS feed.

entry.title: In Lieu of Ads
entry.content:
I recently saw this project in my news feed and wanted to give it a try. It’s a simple rails app that gives you an easy way to accept credit card payments online. I’ve never liked the way that ads looked on my site, so I’m going to run a “tip me” button for a while and see how that works.

If you find one of my posts useful, or if you’d just like to buy me a coffee, give it a try.

entry.title: Trying Out Octopress 2.1
entry.content: This site is now running Octopress 2.1 (still in beta). The most notable new feature is its support for linklogs, which is pretty exciting. Apologies if you see any hiccups in the RSS feed while I tinker with the site.

entry.title: Amazon Static Hosting Cost
entry.content:
A little over a month ago, I moved this site to Amazon S3 Static Hosting. I’ve just received the bill for the first full month using the service. Here are the details.

This is for two websites. The “Reduced Redundancy” portion of the bill has nothing to do with the websites, but is for a bucket where I backup certain files.

So, the real price for hosting two websites on root domains was $1.1. Since I have very low traffic, most of the cost was for Amazon’s DNS service. You have to use their DNS service if you want to use a root domain, but if you keep the www subdomain, you could use your own DNS provider. In my case, if I weren’t using the root domain, my bill would only be about ten cents.

This seems inexpensive, but if you have more than a handful of websites with any meaningful traffic it could start to add up to more than a $9 per month shared hosting plan.

entry.title: Hosting a Naked Domain on Amazon S3
entry.content:
A few months ago I experimented with hosting this website on Amazon S3. It’s trivial to setup an s3 bucket as a website, and ponyHost makes it a breeze to deploy an Octopress website to the bucket. Static HTML/CSS + S3 hosting make for a very snappy website. However, at that time there was no clean way to use S3 to host a root domain, so I abandoned the effort.

Then just this morning, Amazon announced support for root domains with Amazon S3 hosted websites.

I decided to give it a try during lunch. I followed these instructions and in less than an hour I was all finished, save for DNS propagation. This site is now hosted on Amazon’s lightning-fast infrastructure. And if I need to, I can fail back to my shared hosting provider by simply changing the DNS nameservers at my registrar.

One lingering concern I have is cost. Although S3 prices are very economical under normal circumstances, the “Data Transfer Out” component of the pricing means that my monthly bill’s theoretical maximum is effectively infinite. Expensive accidents involving Amazon S3 are not without precedent. Even a single individual with an axe to grind and a 10 megabit home internet connection could do non-trivial damage to my wallet over the course of a month.

I’m sure there are ways to configure logging and/or notifications in a manner that would let me guard against such accidents or attacks, but I have not explored this yet. I’ll take a look at that over the weekend. In the meantime, please let me know if you happen to see any issue with the site.
